I now have less than 8 teeth in my mouth, all of which are broken and destroyed. I can barely walk down my 3 steps out of the house because I’m out of breath, and I’m constantly sore.
I’ve been soda free for a few months now, and I feel wonderful compared to when I drank soda. I now have energy to get up and do stuff. I’m less irritable (that first month was hell! Quitting soda is probably one of the best things for my body I have ever done! I’m currently trying to quit smoking too, but this one is proving to be harder.

I can't drink pure water, so I add a sweetening called petel you can find this in Israel, and I also drink soda and soft drinks. However, I think this does not apply to America, since American soda usually has corn syrup in it, which is awful for the body.
The strict health ministration does what it can to mitigate the sugar and other harmful substances and chemicals in food and drinks. If I were to do what I do now in America, I would most likely suffer severe health problems.

I'm really glad I stopped drinking soda. I used to only drink Soda and milk for many years of my life (not during the same meals of course). Now I always make sure there is water nearby wherever I go, which also reduces a lot of the hunger I used to have. Though water being around also has other uses as well, especially if you want to clean something off quicklike, so even more reason to carry around water.

Here are some things I ran into for drinking 3-5 cans of Coca Cola a day:
1. You get a film built up on your tongue as well making it so everything does not taste as good.
2. Soda (or anything really acidic) is really bad if you want to do vocal work of any kind. So you get a scratchy throat muuuuch faster, and it's harder to do different sounds with your throat.
3. I was always tired.. It was so bad that I got detentions all the time for being late to school, or falling asleep in class. Sometimes I would start dreaming even in my favorite classes, it was just impossible to stay awake!. There were other reasons making me tired, but soda was one of the largest reasons why. Though it does take several weeks (sometimes a month or two) of not drinking soda to not feel tired due to not drinking soda.
4. Soda is really expensive! Especially if you compare it to water, which can be free a lot of the time.
5. Certain food combinations with soda do very strange things to you. Since I love yogurt, I had it with soda one time, and it felt like I could move my teeth around (but didn't hurt), it was very strange. I can only imagine what other strange stuff soda can do when combined with other foods in your stomach.

I'm sure there's other reasons I'm not thinking of that happened to me, but that's just off the top of my head. Basically just do not drink soda.... at least regularly. Though I know it takes me a day or two to recover from soda if I drink enough of it in one day nowadays because it makes me so dang tired.
Not to mention that carbonated beverages increase the risk of renal calculus... but is difficult no to drink soda...

I had a stint where I quit for a couple months a few years back to see if I'd feel different, but I found it to be too costly ( I get probably half of my caloric intake from pop) and not enough immediate benefit to keep it cut out. I'm 36 now, and I'd guess that I'm in the top 15% of physical fitness, while doing very little exercise. (I did workout a lot while younger [10 years ago or so], and very infrequently workout now). My teeth are also in good shape, I brush once a day.

I have no doubt that the long term effects will likely catch up with me, the idea of my telomeres shortening concerns me, but I find it interesting that my genetics would allow for such a diet , while others suffer so badly.

I plan on cutting out pop this summer, as currently I need the sugar and caffeine to get through the rest of the semester . I am concerned how I'll fair in the semester afterward without those to sustain me.

So since I was a kid I drank a lot of soda, mostly diet, as well as water, milk, and juice. I drank more soda though. Now in the last two years I've cut down drastically, but because I wanted to. If I'm really in the mood I'll walk up the street and get a drink or two. Sometimes I have cravings, but few and far between. These don't last very long. I am also not addicted to Caffeine as after three straight months with out a soda I never once had any withdrawal symptoms. I just like soda. Yes I am over weight/obese, but soda was not the main cause, it was due to poor choices by my self and my upbringing. A word to the wise, soda pop consumption should be heavily limited and if possible, gone. I used to be 50 lbs overweight because of bad drinking habits, bad eating habits, and lack of exercise. Nowadays I'm only about 5-10 lbs overweight. I simply cut the soda pop out of my diet and began eating properly, as superficial as it sounds, Paleo diets really do work wonders. Everything can and will kill you. Too much sun will kill you. Not enough sun will kill you. Too much water will kill you. Not enough water will kill you. That's why it's important for people to insert the word "moderation" into their vocabulary. Everyone's built differently. Everyone has different tastes/preferences. That's why I get annoyed with vegans who preach and act superior to those who aren't. I'll drink my soda. I drink only when I'm craving it (when I'm PMSing). I can easily down a 12 case of Mt Dew (reg) in a week--drinking 3-5 a day in succession. And I've learned the hard way to listen to those cravings. This is why diets don't work for most people. You shock your system by cutting out soda (or bread) altogether and you crave it so much, you go crazy and binge eat/drink causing you to gain twice the amount you lost.

(Source: Personal experience and Google)

Human bodies are so complex and amazing. I'm glad this video provided a case study and some facts on what effects you might get out of drinking only soda. I myself am not a scientist, but would have offered a sort of disclaimer in the description or in the video. A disclaimer or clause that stated how ones individual effects could be different from an others. Genetics plays a role in determining someones susceptibility to certain issues, either good or bad. I may not have noticed something indicating results may vary, or it may be common knowledge. The reason I bring this up is in my experience is someone who only drinks soda in addition to smoking cigarettes for at least 20 years completely contradicts the video. To the best of my knowledge has fine teeth, looks younger than those of their age group, is very slender and has no other health issues. I do believe that further down the road complications will arise, but I would include something stating that the outcome is subject to other external factors as well. The video is presented in a way to persuade the audience that the outcomes are certainties. I did hear the word "can" used twice and "may" used once, not counting the quotes of research data and an example. Overall solid job and keep the videos coming as it brings awareness to things people may overlook (2.7+mill views at my count). Best wishes and in no way intended to offend AsapScience, I appreciate the time that went into creating this video.

I've known people only drink regular soda (not water, etc.) their whole lives (upwards of 60 years starting at age 5) with no ill effects, no added weight-gain, no tooth-loss, and are fine. A body can learn over years to work with what it's given (to some degree). Consider the Japanese eating only fish and rice their whole lives with no change in diet. Same amount, same times, etc. They can live upwards of 100 years with obvious vitamin deficiency, perhaps only trace amounts. There is something to be said on consistent diet, even if it's deficient. I argue this because I've seen empirical data in family members and in my travels. Meanwhile, the "food pyramid" rotates on its axis every 20 years or so I've noticed. Health agencies aren't completely certain of short-term findings and studies. I remember back several years ago you should only eat egg yolks, not whites. Now it's the opposite. Evolution or confusion of a health-system?

When I was 12 though, I started drinking cola and became obsessed with it (nothing else tastes as good as cola, period - not soft drinks but cola specifically) in no small part due to it's caffeine killing the headache in fairly large doses (2,000+ causes caffeine headaches, but 500 - 1000 mg a day is perfect).

Years ago (my early 20s) I drank a 12 pk of canned Pepsi a day. I did not drink water, but did drink milk and sometimes (I am guessing when dehydration was really bad) chewed crushed ice. The addiction to caffeine has made quitting all together very difficult.
I was about 130 lbs (I stand 5'3") when this trend started as a result of my employer allowing 'free' fountain sodas but not the juices. So, I drank the free stuff. by the time I left that job I was about 160 lbs. Over the next 4 years I ballooned up to 235 lbs and was too heavy to do much physically. I was dehydrated even though I didn't know it and was plagued by UTIs.
Then I saw a photo of me, full body and wanted to cry. :(
The next day I bought my usual 12pk soda but this time bought a 6 pk WATER. If I wanted a soda I HAD to drink a water... the WHOLE bottle. No leaving a 'bit' at the bottom of the bottle. This helped a lot!!!!
A week of this and I had already lost about 5#. Then I headed to the park down the road and at 4 am I was waddling (your kidding right? I did NOT walk or run at that size I was fooling only me.) I waddled as fast as I could and now and then I'd jog a few steps. Eventually it was the mind game again. "Run from 2nd base to 3rd and you can walk to Home" then it was run one base line walk the next until I was jogging the whole way around.
I would reward my self with a sneakers now and then but not every day. The protein was a little helpful, and I was actually starting to burn a lot more than I was eating. I was trading bowls of Capt Crunch for bowls of salad. And all treats had to be 'earned'. It took about 5-6 months and I was down to about 150.
I did pretty good over the next couple of decades, though my fight to stay off the Pepsi was never over. At current I am back up to 220, mostly due to new job over the last 2 years that has me sitting all night at my computer and then me, sitting at my computer all day and sleeping as well. The Pepsi is back but I am also back on the mind game of a LITER of water to earn a 20 oz soda. I know I need to get up and MOVE. :( But alone at 53 I find motivation lacking. Currently I am looking into walk and hike clubs around the city I live in and I must say there are more than I thought. Going through them I am sure I will find one or two to fit my needs. :)

Not very scientific.  Their point about Corn Syrup "not being metabolized like other sugars" is misleading.  They are actually talking about fructose here, which occurs in equal amounts in ordinary table sugar, and is metabolized differently from glucose, the other half of corn syrup and table sugar.  Also, saying that telomeres shorten in soda drinkers as fast as they do in smokers doesn't say anything if it's the same rate as in it is in non-smoking non-soda-drinkers.  And "the recommended 8 daily glasses of water" comes from a FDA recommendation whose next sentence indicates that you would get this much water from your food normally without drinking any water at all.  You're not going to replace the water in your food with soda.

I usually like ASAP science but this video was lacking and built on some faulty premises. 12 fluid oz of Coke has fewer calories than 12 fl oz of OJ. I'm not suggesting coke is as nutritious as orange juice. Purely from a sugar and calorie perspective they're about the same. Orange juice does have other micronutrients but that doesn't mean that sucking down loads of calories and sugar from 100% fruit juice is good for you though. While we're at it they have approximately similar pH levels. Besides that the idea of suggesting that anyone substitute soda and drink 8 glasses a day because that's the recommended amount of water is also outdated. There's no current medical evidence that we need 8 glasses of water to be healthy. Your body can extract water/hydration from many sources. You don't need to give your hyponatremia. Do yourself a favor. Eat a balanced diet. Eat a variety of nutritious foods, not too much, mostly fruits and vegetables and you will be fine. You can still drink some soda. It's not a death sentence. Just don't be ridiculous and drink a 2 liter every day.

I used to drink 3 cans of soda a day at minimum. Of course, I had water and milk and other beverages as well, stayed active with sports and performing arts and only ate fast food if I was in a bind, but I chugged soda like nobody's business. I've been mistaken for looking younger than I actually am, never had any health problems related to my liver or heart, never got a cavity after increasing my soda intake and my teeth are about as white as some of my non-soda drinking friends. Now that I'm living on my own, I don't even keep soda in the fridge. I've been a little more inactive and eat fast food a little more, but soda is a rarity. Not much has changed. Who knows, maybe I'm the exception.

Basically, don't let soda be your only intake with no sort of physical activity all day. You can have it every now and again, even if it's a can or two daily. Just balance it out by eating better (not necessarily less) and moving around.

I primarily drink soda, and have done so for many years (since my teens, currently thirty). I rarely drink anything else, and I have experienced absolutely zero negative health effects. I have always had clean lab tests (kidney/liver/blood count/sugar/etc) whenever I go for physicals/test, I am of average weight, I rarely exercise, etc.

I'm sure there's a lot on the same boat as me.

As for the unfortunate individuals who do experience negative health effects, it's not too far-fetched to blame genetics on those. If you have genetics that determine that you're prone to heart issues, diabetes, liver/kidney problems, brain issues, weight gain, etc. Then yes, you may see one or more of those if you fuel them with food and drink that promote those negative issues. However if you come from a family of no adverse health issues and were lucky to inherit these good stable health related genes/dna.. then you can most likely drink and eat anything you want and experience zero negative health issues.

The "link" between the sweet taste and weight gain comes from a correlative study that looked at 4000 people, their weights and their eating habits.  The researchers noticed that fat people tended to drink diet soda, and skinny people drank sugared soda.  The media then incorrectly determined, therefore, that diet soda made people fat (instead of: heavy people are trying to lose weight, and drink diet soda for that reason).  This incorrect reasoning became popular in the media with people coming up with all sorts of theories about why this might be, including the "insulin fake-out" theory.  A prospective, controlled trial in Scandinavia showed that, of course, when you substitute sugared drinks with artificially sweetened drinks, the people who drink sugared drinks gained weight, and the ones drinking diet soda did not.

The 'facts' mentioned here about diet drinks are really shaky. I've looked at some of those studies, and the ones I've seen are really bad studies and cannot really conclude anything. The bit about diet soda drinking people rewarding themselves with more food is the only bit of data that holds up here.

And in general most of the stuff here is just because of the sugar. Drinking that much fruit juice does exactly the same (and is more acidic for your teeth), and doesn't give you most of the benefits of eating fruit either. Eating that much sugar is going to shorten your telomeres just as effectively. It's just that we don't notice how much sugar we're drinking, which makes it easy to take in way more than we should.

This entire video is complete scientific bullshit. I'm really disappointed in you, AsapScience. You cherry-picked which science you reported on and used the ones with questionable methods and no actual data or experimentation, but just model claims. Meanwhile, there are several systematic reviews and literature reviews on the topic that say otherwise. The only accurate evidence in this video is that these things happen at super high consumption of fructose. We're talking at the 30 cans a day level.

And, yes, this video is titled "What if you only drank soda", but you didn't clarify that in the video at all. You made it seem like drinking any soda will cause these things. So, SHAME ON YOU. Spreading anti-science fearmongering is just shameful.

Sources:
Rizkalla SW. Health implications of fructose consumption: A review of recent data. Nutr Metab (Lond). 2010 Nov 4;7:82.

Sievenpiper JL, de Souza RJ, Mirrahimi A, Yu ME, Carleton AJ, Beyene J, Chiavaroli L, Di Buono M, Jenkins AL, Leiter LA, Wolever TM, Kendall CW, Jenkins DJ. Effect of fructose on body weight in controlled feeding trials: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Ann Intern Med. 2012 Feb 21;156(4):291-304.

Tappy L, Le KA. Metabolic effects of fructose and the worldwide increase in obesity. Physiol Rev. 2010 Jan;90(1):23-46. Review.

Dolan LC, Potter SM, Burdock GA. Evidence-based review of the effect of normal dietary consumption of fructose on development of hyperlipidemia and obesity in healthy, normal weight individuals. Crit Rev Food Sci Nutr. 2010 Jan;50(1):53-84. Review.

Hey Asap, I love your videos and that's exactly why I feel the need to criticize a point of this video, perhaps during their bibliographic review you have been based on animal model studies when it comes to diets sodas, and yes, animal studies indicate that artificial sweeteners actually increase appetite probably by deregulating the brain calorie count associated with high-energy foods, in addition to having a negative effect on insulin and fat metabolism. However human studies indicate the opposite as can be seen in this review published by the International Journal of Obesity: http://www.nature.com/ijo/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/ijo2015177a.html
Which suggests that in humans the consumption of artificial sweeteners may lead to weight reduction, improved lipid profile, decreased appetite, among others. I'm not here advocating anything, just think warn of interesting, and certainly there downsides regarding the consumption of diet sodas.

I used to drink 2-3 sodas a day and got pretty heavy. Since I have greatly reduced my soda intake (I now drink water most of the time) and completely gotten rid of the "colas" (if I do drink a soda, now it's lemon-lime, like Sprite), I have found that it's pretty easy to lose weight. I also have sworn off all caffeine, so no coffee or tea for me. (I don't like their taste either; adding tons of sugar was the only way I could enjoy them. But since adding sugar to coffee and tea is just like drinking sodas, that's not a good idea.)

Anyone who consumes a lot of sugar and/or high fructose corn syrup (HFCS) or even regular corn syrup will likely have a lot of health complications, like that woman mentioned in the video. You do NOT need to completely cut out all carbs (the low-carb diet is pretty dangerous after a while), but greatly reducing or even eliminating the "simple carbs" (like sugar, HFCS, corn syrup, etc.) will do wonders for your overall health. Do not cut out "complex carbs" (bread, cereal, etc.) because your body still needs it. The key is moderation. Reducing your total caloric intake is very important, but the type and proportions of the stuff you consume is also important.

The "drink 8 glasses of water a day" is a myth that probably comes from a poor reading a 1945 report.
http://www.sciencealert.com/there-s-no-evidence-we-need-to-drink-eight-glasses-of-water-a-day-researcher-advises "So where did the great water myth come from? It's generally believed that the source is a 1945 Food and Nutrition Board Recommendation that declared, "a suitable allowance of water for adults is 2.5 litres daily in most instances. An ordinary standard for diverse persons is 1 millilitre for each calorie of food". As you might have guessed, 2.5 litres more or less works out to be around eight glasses. But what's usually ignored from that report is the crucial next sentence: "Most of this quantity is contained in prepared foods."
